facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1942 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1942 of 1966. Appeal from the Judgment and decree dated April 23, 1963 of the Pat

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and decree dated April 23, 1963 of Patna High Court in First Appeal No. 420 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and decree dated April 23, 1963 of the Patna High Court in First Appeal No. 420 of 1955. Sarjoo Prasad and R. C. Prasad, for the appellant.

facts.text: Suit instituted by appellant (plaintiff Bank) against State of Bihar as defendant No. 1, Jagdishpur Zamindari Co. Ltd. as defendant No. 2, and its directors as defendants 3 to 5.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by certificate from a decree of the Patna High Court in a suit instituted by the appellant against the State of Bihar which was impleaded as defendant No. 1, the other defendants being the Jagdishpur Zamindari Co. Ltd.  defendant No. 2  and some of its directors defendants 3 to 5.

facts.text: Defendant No. 2 entered into cash credit system agreement with plaintiff's Arrah Branch for pledging sugar.

anchor.surface_text: According to the allegations in the plaint one of the methods of making advances followed by the plaintiff Bank was that the companystituents pledged their merchandise on a cash credit system with the Bank and took advances on the pledged goods. ... The defendant No. 2 entered into a cash credit system agreement with the plaintiffs Arrah Branch, the arrangement being that the sugar would be pledged under the cash credit system.

facts.text: On December 16, 1946, advance made to defendant No. 2 stood at Rs. 3,20,486-2-0 and Bank held 6239 bags of different varieties of sugar as security.

anchor.surface_text: On December 16, 1946 the advance made to defendant No. 2 stood at Rs. 3,20,486-2-0 and the Bank held 6239 bags of different varieties of sugar as security. These bags were kept in godowns provided by defendant No. 2.

facts.text: Bags of sugar kept in godowns provided by defendant No. 2, key of each godown in custody of the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: These bags were kept in godowns provided by defendant No. 2. The key of the lock of each godown was in the custody of the Bank.

facts.text: In December 1949, under seizure order issued by defendant No. 1, Rationing Officer and District Magistrate Patna broke open godown locks and removed 1818 bags of 27D quality sugar weighing about 5000 maunds.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that in December 1949 under companyer of an illegal seizure order issued by defendant No. 1 the Rationing Officer and the District Magistrate, Patna, got the locks of the godown broken open and forcibly and illegally removed 1818 bags of 27D quality of sugar. They total quantity removed weighed about 5,000 maunds.

facts.text: No payment made to plaintiff Bank which held the bags as pledgee under cash credit agreement.

anchor.surface_text: No payment was made to the plaintiff Bank which held the bags of sugar as pledgee under the cash credit agreement.

facts.text: Plaintiff prayed for decree for return of 1818 bags or Rs. 1,81,700-9-3 with interest or alternatively Rs. 93,910-10-9 against defendant No. 2 and others.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff prayed for a decree for the return of 1818 bags of 27D quality sugar and, alternatively for re- companyery of Rs. 1,81,700-9-3 with interest by way of damages for illegal removal and detention of sugar or. price thereof. Alternatively a decree for Rs. 93,910-10-9 was claimed against defendant No. 2 and the other defendants.

facts.text: Seizure effected pursuant to lawful orders; sale proceeds of about 5000 mds. sugar included in Rs. 1,50,039-10-9 deposited in treasury, later attached by Certificate Officer Patna under Public Demands Recovery Act for arrears of sugar cess Rs. 2 lakhs due from Bhita Sugar Factory.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted by defendant No. 1 on the ground that the seizure had been effected pursuant to lawful orders which had been made and that the sale proceeds of about 5000 mds. of sugar were included in the sum of Rs. 1,50,039-10-9 which was deposited in the treasury but which was later on attached under the orders of Certificate Officer, Patna, under the Public Demands Recovery Act on account of arrears of sugar cess amounting to Rs. 2 lakhs due from the Bhita Sugar Factory with which defendant No. 2 had entered into an arrangement

facts.text: Defendant No. 2 entered into arrangement with Bhita Sugar Factory pursuant to which entire quantity of sugar including 5000 maunds seized came into possession of defendant No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: due from the Bhita Sugar Factory with which defendant No. 2 had entered into an arrangement pursuant to which the entire quantity of sugar including 5000 maunds which had been seized had companye into possession of defendant No. 2.

facts.text: Issue No. 6a: Was the sugar seized by the government in possession of the Bank as a pledgee at the time of the seizure and have the rights of the Bank as such pledgee been determined by the seizure?

anchor.surface_text: We may only mention issue No. 6 a  which will be material for determination of the points which we have been called upon to decide Was the sugar seized by the government in possession of the Bank as a pledgee at the time of the seizure and have the rights of the Bank as such pledgee been determined by the seizure in question?

facts.text: Trial court held order of seizure valid; plaintiff's right as pledgee could not be extinguished by seizure; attachment order legal on def2 but not binding on Bank; decree against def1 for Rs. 93,910-10-9 with 6% interest from suit date.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that the order of seizure in respect of the stock of sugar was valid. It was further held that the plaintiffs right as a pledgee companyld number be extinguished by seizure of the sugar in its possession and though the attachment order of the Certificate Officer was legal and binding on defendant No. 2 it was number binding on the Bank  plaintiff  and it companyld be effective only in respect of that portion of the price which was number necessary for the liquidation of the dues of the plaintiff from defendant No. A decree was passed in favour of the plaintiff against defendant No. 1 only for Rs. 93,910-10-9 with interest at 6 per annum from the date of the suit till realisation.

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 (State of Bihar) filed appeal to Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant No. 1  State of Bihar  filed an appeal to the High Court.

facts.text: Patna High Court set aside decree against defendant No. 1, granted decree against defendant No. 2 and others, holding plaintiff not entitled due to lawful seizure and certificate proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that in the presence of the finding that the plaintiff had number been wrongfully deprived of the sugar on account of the lawful seizure or its price owing to the certificate proceedings started by the Cane Commissioner the plaintiff was number entitled to any decree against the State. But it was entitled to a decree against defendant No. 2 and the other defendants. Consequently a decree against defendant No. 1 was set aside and instead of decree was granted against the other defendants.

facts.text: It is common ground that plaintiff (appellant) held the seized sugar as security for payment of debts or advances to defendant No. 2 in cash credit account.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is companymon ground that the plaintiff  which is the appellant before us  held the sugar which was seized from its custody as security for payment of the debts or advances made to defendant No. 2 in its cash credit account.

facts.text: There were arrears of certain cess due from defendant No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: There were arrears of certain cess due from defendant No. 2.

facts.text: Cane Commissioner took proceedings under Public Demands Recovery Act and attached price of sugar deposited in Government Treasury instead of paying to plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: As stated before, the Cane Commissioner took proceedings under the Public Demands Recovery Act and attached the price of the sugar which had been deposited by the appropriate authorities in the Government Treasury instead of being paid to the plaintiff.

facts.text: Cane Commissioner indisputably did not have right of priority over secured creditors like the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: The Cane Commissioner indisputably did number have any right of priority over the other creditors of defendant No. 2 and, in particular, the secured creditors.

facts.text: Sugar had been seized and then sold.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the sugar had been seized and then sold.

facts.text: Defendants 3 to 5 did not file any appeal against High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 3 to 5 did number file any appeal against the judgment of the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court judgment and decree dismissing suit against State of Bihar, grants decree against State in terms of trial court.

anchor.surface_text: In the view that we have taken the appeal is allowed, the judgment and decree of the High Court dismissing the suit against the State, of Bihar is hereby set aside and a decree is granted against the State of Bihar in the same terms as was granted by the trial companyrt.

under the Public Demands Recovery Act on account of arrears of sugar cess amounting to Rs. 2 lakhs due from the Bhita Sugar Factory with which defendant No. 2 had entered into an arrangement pursuant to which the entire quantity of sugar including 5000 maunds which had been seized had come into possession of defendant No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: the Cane Commissioner took proceedings under the Public Demands Recovery Act and attached the price of the sugar which had been deposited by the appropriate authorities in the Government Treasury instead of being paid to the plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: Section 172 of the Contract Act defines a pledge to mean the bailment of goods as security for payment of debt or performance of a promise. The bailor is called the pawnor and the bailee is called the pawnee.

concepts.interpretation: Defines pledge as bailment for security, establishing pawnor and pawnee roles central to bank's position.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: en a simple lien and a mortgage which wholy passed the property in the thing companyveyed 1 . The Pawnee hag a special property or special interest in

anchor.surface_text: Section 173 of that Act provides that the pawnee may retain the goods pledged not only for the payment of the debt or performance of the promise but also for the interest of the debt etc.

concepts.interpretation: Allows pawnee retention for debt and interest, supporting bank's security rights.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: en a simple lien and a mortgage which wholy passed the property in the thing companyveyed 1 . The Pawnee hag a special property or special interest in

concepts.unlisted_description: Pawnee's right to retain pledged goods

anchor.surface_text: Section 176 is in the following terms If the pawnor makes default in payment of the debt, or performance, at the stipulated time of the promise, in respect of which the goods were pledged, the pawnee may bring a suit against the pawner upon the debt or promise, and retain the goods pledged as a collateral security or he may sell the thing pledged, on giving the pawnor reasonable notice of the sale. If the proceeds of such sale are less than the amount due in respect of the debt or promise, the pawnor is still liable to pay the balance. If the proceeds of the sale are greater than the amount so due, the pawnee shall pay over the surplus to the pawnor.

concepts.interpretation: Empowers pawnee to sue or sell on default, with surplus to pawnor; seizure does not defeat this right.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: en a simple lien and a mortgage which wholy passed the property in the thing companyveyed 1 . The Pawnee hag a special property or special interest in

anchor.surface_text: Section 180 is to the effect that if a third person wrongfully deprives the bailee of the use of the possession of the goods bailed or does him any injury the bailee is entitled to use such remedies as the owner might have used in the like case if no bailment had been made and either the bailor or the bailee may bring a suit against a third person for such deprivation or injury.

concepts.interpretation: Third person (Government) depriving pawnee (bailee) entitles pawnee to remedies; applied to hold State liable despite lawful seizure.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: en a simple lien and a mortgage which wholy passed the property in the thing companyveyed 1 . The Pawnee hag a special property or special interest in

concepts.unlisted_description: Bailee's remedies against third party deprivation

anchor.surface_text: According to Section 181 whatever is obtained by way of relief or compensation in any such suit shall, as between the bailor and bailee, be dealt with according to their respective interests.

concepts.interpretation: Relief or compensation distributed according to bailor-bailee interests; supports pawnee's claim priority.

issues.text: Was the sugar seized by the government in possession of the Bank as a pledgee at the time of the seizure and have the rights of the Bank as such pledgee been determined by the seizure in question?

anchor.surface_text: Was the sugar seized by the government in possession of the Bank as a pledgee at the time of the seizure and have the rights of the Bank as such pledgee been determined by the seizure in question?

issues.text: Can the rights of the Pawnee who had parted with money in favour of the pawnor on the security of the goods be defeated by the goods being lawfully seized by the Government and the money being made available to other creditors of the pawnor without the claim of the Pawnee being fully satisfied?

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court is in error in considering that the rights of the Pawnee who had parted with money in favour of the pawnor on the security of the goods can be defeated by the goods being lawfully seized by the Government and the money being made available to other creditors of the pawnor without the claim of the Pawnee being fully satisfied.

issues.text: Does the Cane Commissioner have any right of priority over the other creditors of defendant No. 2 and, in particular, the secured creditors?

anchor.surface_text: The Cane Commissioner indisputably did not have any right of priority over the other creditors of defendant No. 2 and, in particular, the secured creditors.

holdings.text: In our judgment the High Court is in error in considering that the rights of the Pawnee who had parted with money in favour of the pawnor on the security of the goods can be defeated by the goods being lawfully seized by the Government and the money being made available to other creditors of the pawnor without the claim of the Pawnee being fully satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court is in error in considering that the rights of the Pawnee who had parted with money in favour of the pawnor on the security of the goods can be defeated by the goods being lawfully seized by the Government and the money being made available to other creditors of the pawnor without the claim of the Pawnee being fully satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court view rejected based on pawnee's special property under Contract Act ss.172-181 and English law precedents; lawful seizure does not extinguish pledgee's rights without satisfaction.

holdings.text: The Pawnee has special property and a lien which is not of ordinary nature on the goods and so long as his claim is not satisfied no other creditor of the pawnor has any right to take away the goods or its price.

anchor.surface_text: The Pawnee has special property and a lien which is not of ordinary nature on the goods and so long as his claim is not satisfied no other creditor of the pawnor has any right to take away the goods or its price.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from Contract Act definitions (ss.172,173,176) and Halsbury's description distinguishing from mere lien; transferable special interest protects against third-party claims.

holdings.text: After the goods had been seized by the Government it was bound to pay the amount due to the plaintiff and the balance could have been made available to satisfy the claim of other creditors of the pawner.

anchor.surface_text: After the goods had been seized by the Government it was bound to pay the amount due to the plaintiff and the balance could have been made available to satisfy the claim of other creditors of the pawner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government steps into shoes post-seizure; must respect pawnee priority under s.176 remedies and s.180 third-party deprivation before distributing to unsecured creditors.

holdings.text: But by a mere act of lawful seizure the Government could not deprive the plaintiff of the amount which was secured by the pledge of the goods to it. As the act of the Government resulted in deprivation of the amount to which the plaintiff was entitled it was bound to reimburse the plaintiff for such amount which the plaintiff in ordinary course would have realized by sale of the goods pledged with it on the pawnor making a default in payment of debt.

anchor.surface_text: But by a mere act of lawful seizure the Government could not deprive the plaintiff of the amount which was secured by the pledge of the goods to it. As the act of the Government resulted in deprivation of the amount to which the plaintiff was entitled it was bound to reimburse the plaintiff for such amount which the plaintiff in ordinary course would have realized by sale of the goods pledged with it on the pawnor making a default in payment of debt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies ss.180-181: third-party (Government) deprivation entitles bailee/pawnee to owner's remedies and compensation per respective interests; pledge security not replaced by seizure.

holdings.text: The approach of the trial court was unexceptionable. The plaintiffs right as a Pawnee could not be extinguished by the seizure of the goods in its possession inasmuch as the pledge of the goods was not meant to replace the liability under the cash credit agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The approach of the trial court was unexceptionable. The plaintiffs right as a Pawnee could not be extinguished by the seizure of the goods in its possession inasmuch as the pledge of the goods was not meant to replace the liability under the cash credit agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms trial court application of pledge rights under Contract Act; seizure does not discharge underlying debt or security purpose.

holdings.text: The Cane Commissioner who was an unsecured creditor could not have any higher rights than the pawnor and was entitled only to the surplus money after satisfaction of the plaintiffs dues.

anchor.surface_text: The Cane Commissioner who was an unsecured creditor could not have any higher rights than the pawnor and was entitled only to the surplus money after satisfaction of the plaintiffs dues.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unsecured creditor subordinate to pawnee's special lien; follows s.176 sale proceeds distribution.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court is in error in considering that the rights of the Pawnee who had parted with money in favour of the pawnor on the security of the goods can be defeated by the goods being lawfully seized by the Government and the money being made available to other creditors of the pawnor without the claim of the Pawnee being fully satisfied.

In the view that we have taken the appeal is allowed, the judgment and decree of the High Court dismissing the suit against the State, of Bihar is hereby set aside and a decree is granted against the State of Bihar in the same terms

anchor.surface_text: But by a mere act of lawful seizure the Government could not deprive the plaintiff of the amount which was secured by the pledge of the goods to it. As the act of the Government resulted in deprivation of the amount to which the plaintiff was entitled it was bound to reimburse the plaintiff for such amount which the plaintiff in ordinary course would have realized by sale of the goods pledged with it on the pawnor making a default in payment of debt.
